election_record.label: Virginia 1809 U.S. House of Representatives, District 2

overview.note: "It is with pleasure we announce the election of major Stephenson, in opposition to Mr. Morrow, in the district composed of the counties of Berkely, Hampshire and Jefferson, by a majority of 231 votes." Alexandria Daily Gazette, Commercial and Political (Alexandria, VA). April 22, 1809.
"Major Stevenson [sic] is elected by a majority in every county in the district." Charleston Courier, May 10, 1809; and, The Pittsburgh Gazette (Pittsburgh, PA), May 10, 1809.

"Major Stephenson, (Fed.) majority over Col. Morrow (Dem.), Jefferson County 32, Berkely County 127, Hampshire County 72, Total Majority 231. Federal Members to the state legislature are chosen from the above counties." Poulson's American Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA). April 24, 1809.

"Jefferson County, Major Stephenson, (fed.) majority over J. Morrow (dem.), 32, Berkely County, Maj. Stephenson, majority 127, Hampshire County, Maj. Stephenson, majority, 72, Total Majority 231." The Minerva (Raleigh, NC). May 4, 1809.

sub_unit.name: Hampshire
sub_unit.note: "Winchester, April 21...The eletion for a member of congress...The Hampshire...polls closed on Monday evening, and stood as follows. Hampshire, Maj. Stephenson 312, Col. Morrow, demo. 239. The Washington Federalist (Georgetown, DC). April 27, 1809.

sub_unit.name: Jefferson
sub_unit.note: "Martinsburg, April 12...The Sun of Federalism rising among the hills. -- We congratulate our federal republican friends upon the event of the election held yesterday in Jefferson county -- at the close of the poll it stood thus:...Federal majority, 32." Norfolk Gazette and Publick Ledger (Norfolk, VA), April 21, 1809; The True American and Commercial Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA), April 21, 1809; and, United States' Gazette (Philadelphia, PA), April 21, 1809.
"On Tuesday last an election was held in this town for choosing a member of Congress...The following is a statement of the votes given." Farmer's Repository (Charlestown, WV). April 14, 1809.
New-Jersey Telescope (Newark, NJ) and Litchfield Gazette (Litchfield, CT) give 237 votes for James Stephenson and 204 votes for John Morrow, however, both papers give the Federal Majority as 32.
